intro: Chenopodium tripteris, commonly known as New Zealand spinach, is an annual herbaceous plant native to New Zealand. It belongs to the Amaranthaceae family and is characterized by its succulent, edible leaves that are rich in nutrients. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with alternate, lobed leaves and small, greenish flowers. It thrives in temperate climates and is often cultivated as a leafy vegetable. Its rapid growth and ability to tolerate poor soil conditions make it a versatile and hardy plant.
